docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: I am among the bewildered you refer to in ''Criticism of Drug Benefit Is Simple: It's Bewildering'' (news article, June 22). As the mother of a disabled adult, I still can't understand why you refer to the elderly and not the disabled, to whom all this legislation also refers. It is a given in all such reporting. It seems to me that we cannot get the ''benefits'' right while refusing to acknowledge who the recipients are.
docs.abstract: Rosemary Strauss letter on June 22 article notes Medicare also covers disabled, who find drug costs major burden

docs.lead_paragraph: Suburbanites are more likely than people in cities or the countryside to turn to complementary or alternative medical remedies to help with pain, according to a study in the current issue of The American Journal of Public Health. The study was led by Dr. April Hazard Vallerand of the Wayne State University College of Nursing in Detroit.
docs.abstract: Study, led by Dr April Hazard Vallerand of Wayne State University College of Nursing in Detroit and published in American Journal of Public Health, finds 30% of individuals who use alternative therapies to deal with pain do not discuss personal remedy with their doctor; demographically, 82% of suburban dwellers have tried alternate therapies while 77% of city residents and 58% of rural residents have also used them; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: Suburbanites are more likely than people in cities or the countryside to turn to complementary or alternative medical remedies to help with pain, according to a study in the current issue of The American Journal of Public Health.     The study was...

docs.lead_paragraph: When Trish M. Perl, a leading American epidemiologist, went to Toronto two weeks ago, she found an exhausted hospital system and workers who were both angry and overwhelmed. Dr. Perl is one of a small number of American doctors who, in response to pleas from her Canadian colleagues, have gone to Toronto over the past several weeks to give health workers a brief respite.

headline.main: Behind the Mask, The Fear of SARS

docs.abstract: Dr Trish M Perl, Johns Hopkins University chief hospital epidemiologist and volunteer to relieve health care workers in Toronto, gives insight into Canada's battle with SARS; describes fear and stress of overworked hospital staff while praising preparedness; Canadian infectious disease specialists appealed to US for help, with offer to pay expenses and $1,400 daily; around 300 doctors volunteered; surreal environment described; hospital workers must wear protective clothing at meetings and are quarantined; photos (M)
docs.snippet: When Trish M. Perl, a leading American epidemiologist, went to Toronto two weeks ago, she found an exhausted hospital system and workers who were both angry and overwhelmed.    Dr. Perl is one of a small number of American doctors who, in response to...

docs.lead_paragraph: Tenet Healthcare, the struggling for-profit hospital chain, told investors yesterday to expect significantly lower profits this year than they had anticipated. The company, which is under regulatory scrutiny for its Medicare billing practices, blamed higher costs and its limited success in negotiating more favorable prices with private health plans for care. Tenet also said it expected lower reimbursements from Medicare and state governments under Medicaid.

headline.main: Already Battered, Tenet Reduces Earnings Forecast For Rest of Year

docs.abstract: Tenet Healthcare tells investors to expect significantly lower profits this year than anticipated; company, which is under regulatory scrutiny for its Medicare billing practices, blames higher costs and its limited success in negotiating more favorable prices with private health plans for care; also expects lower reimbursements from Medicare and state governments under Medicaid; acting chief executive Trevor Fetter comments; graph; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Apple to Use I.B.M. Chip For Its Newest Computers Steven Jobs, left, the chief executive of Apple Computer, introduced an alliance with I.B.M. that will install a powerful 64-bit microprocessor chip on Apple computers. The new G5 chip, Mr. Jobs said, is also the foundation for the company's future software developments that will be based on an updated version of its OS X operating system -- called Panther -- that Apple will begin selling before the end of the year. [Page C6.]

docs.lead_paragraph: President Bush raised the pressure today on Congress to pass a Medicare drug bill this week, even as conservatives in his own party criticized the legislation and pushed for changes. For the second consecutive week, the Senate debated amendments to the legislation, which would offer new prescription drug benefits to 40 million elderly and disabled Americans on Medicare, at a cost of $400 billion in the next 10 years.

headline.main: Bush Seeks Medicare Drug Bill That Conservatives Oppose

docs.abstract: Pres Bush increases pressure on Congress to approve Medicare drug bill this week, even as conservative Republicans score bill and push for changes to restrain spending growth and spur beneficiaries to join private health plans; Senate continues to debate bill amendments; Republican leaders expect bill to pass Senate soon with broad bipartisan majority; Bush is expected to meet with House conservatives later this week to allay their concerns about creating new entitlement to drug coverage without, in their view, adequate 'reform' of program; Rep John Shadegg, influential conservative, opposes bill (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A collection of sample pills, a sink, an ivy wallpaper border, a free blood work-up. A scale, new glasses, an afternoon a week. Dozens of kindnesses, cobbled together at no onerous cost, have evolved into a doctor's office that offers free medical care to the residents of the Bowery Mission and the people who eat at its soup kitchen. On a street where the failed and fallen apart have historically held sway, the accumulation of healthful gifts is welcome.

headline.main: Bowery Journal; A Clinic Where Simple Gifts Add Up

docs.abstract: Doctor's office that offers free medical care to residents of Bowery Mission opens, thanks to donations and volunteers; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In the dying hours of this year's legislative session, New York State lawmakers approved changes to an arcane law that, after years on the books, was blamed for threatening a malpractice insurance crisis for hospitals this year. On Friday, the State Senate and Assembly, in an agreement with Gov. George E. Pataki, passed a bill altering the law, responding not only to hospitals' complaints, but also to a rare plea from the state's highest court. In April, a reluctant but unanimous Court of Appeals upheld a $140 million judgment against New York Presbyterian Hospital, but in an unusual departure from their customary detachment, the judges disparaged the result and the law that produced it, and asked the Legislature to consider changing the statute.

headline.main: Lawmakers Vote to Limit Hospital Malpractice Costs

docs.abstract: New York State lawmakers approve changes to arcane law that is being blamed for threatening a malpractice insurance crisis for hospitals this year; complaint is that there is nothing in law to prevent jury from applying its own inflation adjustment to award, or to stop plaintiffs' lawyers from encouraging juries to do so; that would greatly inflate final judgment; Court of Appeals reluctantly but unanimously upheld $140 million judgment against New York Presbyterian Hospital last April, but in unusual departure, judges asked Legislature to consider changing law; New York Public Interest Research Group, which questioned need to amend law, now says Legislature has made good attempt to balance all considerations (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: ''More Americans Seeking Help for Depression'' (front page, June 18) reflects continuing progress in destigmatizing depression. The bad news is what was considered adequate treatment by the National Comorbidity Study.
docs.abstract: Dr Kerry J Sulkowicz letter warns that few sessions of counseling are better than nothing but cannot make dent in treating serious depression
